org.threadly.litesockets

Class NoThreadSocketExecuter

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.util.AbstractService
      • org.threadly.litesockets.NoThreadSocketExecuter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SocketExecuterInterface, org.threadly.util.ServiceInterface

    public class NoThreadSocketExecuter
extends org.threadly.util.AbstractService
implements SocketExecuterInterface

    The NoThreadSocketExecuter is a simpler implementation of a SocketExecuterInterface that does not create any threads. Since there are no threads operations happen on whatever thread calls .select(), and only 1 thread at a time should ever call it at a time. Other then that it should be completely thread safe.

    This is generally the implementation used by clients. It can be used for servers but only when not servicing many connections at once. How many connections is hardware and OS defendant. For an average multi-core x86 linux server I a connections not to much more then 1000 connections would be its limit, though alot depends on how active those connections are.

    It should also be noted that all client read/close callbacks happen on the thread that calls select().

    The functions like addClient(Client), removeClient(Client), addServer(Server), and removeServer(Server) can be called from other threads safely.

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.threadly.litesockets.SocketExecuterInterface

    • Constructor Detail

      • NoThreadSocketExecuter

        public NoThreadSocketExecuter()
        Constructs a NoThreadSocketExecuter. AbstractService.start() must still be called before using it.

    • Method Detail

      • wakeup

        public void wakeup()
        This is used to wakeup the Selector assuming it was called with a timeout on it. Most all methods in this class that need to do a wakeup do it automatically, but there are situations where you might want to wake up the thread we are blocked on manually.

      • addClient

        public void addClient(Client client)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        Add a Client to this SocketExecuter. If the client needs to be connected the SocketExecuterInterfaces Implementor must finish the connection, once done the client will be able to read and write to the socket.

        Specified by:
        addClient in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        client - the Client you are adding.

      • removeClient

        public void removeClient(Client client)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        Remove a Client that has been added to this SocketExecuter. Once this is done the client will no longer be able to read/write to the socket. If a write buffer for the client exists it might not be completely flushed out yet. All reads should be at least queued in the Executer for a Read action.

        Specified by:
        removeClient in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        client - the Client to remove from the SocketExecuter

      • addServer

        public void addServer(Server server)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        This is used to add a Server to a SocketExecuter. Once its added the Server can begin accepting and processing new connections to it.

        Specified by:
        addServer in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        server - adds a Server to this SocketExecuter.

      • removeServer

        public void removeServer(Server server)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        This is used to remove Server from a SocketExecuter. Once a server is removed it will no longer process new connections. It is important to note removing a Server does not close any listen ports, you must Server.close() on the Server to do that. Calling Server.close() will automatically remove the Server from the SocketExecuter.

        Specified by:
        removeServer in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        server - removes a Server from the SocketExecuter

      • flagNewWrite

        public void flagNewWrite(Client client)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        Flags a clients as having a newWrite pending. The Client must already be added via SocketExecuterInterface.addClient(Client). This notify the SocketExecuter to check it to see if the Client can write. This should only be called if the Client is transitioning from a non-write state to a write state.

        Generally this is only used internally by a Client and unless otherwise stated should not need to be done unless implementing your own Client.

        Specified by:
        flagNewWrite in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        client - the Client to flag for new write.

      • flagNewRead

        public void flagNewRead(Client client)
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        This will notify the SocketExecuter that the Client can now be read from. The Client will automatically be removed from the read operations if its maxBufferSize for reads was hit.

        Generally this is only used internally by a Client and unless otherwise stated should not need to be done unless implementing your own Client.

        Specified by:
        flagNewRead in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Parameters:
        client - the Client to flag for new Read.

      • getClientCount

        public int getClientCount()
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        Get the count of Client on this SocketExecuter.

        Specified by:
        getClientCount in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Returns:
        the number of clients.

      • getServerCount

        public int getServerCount()
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        Get the count of Server from the SocketExecuter.

        Specified by:
        getServerCount in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Returns:
        the number of Servers.

      • getThreadScheduler

        public org.threadly.concurrent.SchedulerServiceInterface getThreadScheduler()
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        This returns the current SimpleSchedulerInterface for this SocketExecuter. Every SocketExecuter must have some kind of a SimpleSchedulerInterface for it to execute client/server operations on.

        Specified by:
        getThreadScheduler in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Returns:
        returns the SimpleSchedulerInterface the SocketExecuter is using.

      • select

        public void select()
        This will run all ExecuterTasks, check for pending network operations, then run those operations. There can be a lot of I/O operations so this could take some time to run. In general it should not be called from things like GUI threads.

      • select

        public void select(int delay)
        This is the same as the select() but it allows you to set a delay. This delay is the time to wait for socket operations to happen. It will block the calling thread for up to this amount of time, but it could be less if any network operation happens (including another thread adding a client/server).
        Parameters:
        delay - Max time in milliseconds to block for.

      • getStats

        public SimpleByteStats getStats()
        Description copied from interface: SocketExecuterInterface

        This will give you read and write stats for the SocketExecuter. This will tell you information about the number of bytes sent/received by this SocketExecuter.

        Specified by:
        getStats in interface SocketExecuterInterface
        Returns:
        a SimpleByteStats object to allow you to get the stats for this SocketExecuter.
